VERTICE PHARMA UK PARENT LIMITED
 
 
GROUP STRATEGIC REPORT
FOR THE YEAR ENDED 31 DECEMBER 2019

Principal activity and business review
 
Vertice Pharma UK Parent Limited ("Vertice Pharma") is a specialty pharmaceutical company focused on improving patients' health. Vertice Pharma develops, manufactures, markets and distributes high quality and affordable pharmaceutical products through its operating companies. The company markets generic pharmaceuticals and over-the-counter products for hospital market, retail pharmacy and specialised clinical settings predominantly in the United States. Vertice Pharma has global headquarters in the United Kingdom and United States headquarters in New Jersey. The directors are satisfied with the performance of the company during the year.

Future developments
 
The directors have no plans to alter the activities of the company for the foreseeable future.

Principal risks and uncertainties
 
The directors consider that the principal risks and uncertainties facing the company are as follows:
Market risk
The company operates predominantly in the U.S. generic pharmaceutical market. Any changes to the U.S. Healthcare law and regulations affecting generic pharmaceuticals market may have an impact on the company. Furthermore, potential competitive entries may have an impact both on price and volume of the products sold. The company monitors the market very closely both through internal and external resources to position itself against any potential market risk.
Regulatory risk
The company complies with the rules and regulations set by a number of authorities including the U.S. Food and Drug Administration. The company invests significant amounts of its resources in achieving highest compliance standards by employing qualified talents and professional service providers and monitoring the key performance factors at executive management meetings on a regular basis.
Financial risk
The company has budgetary and financial reporting procedures, supported by appropriate key performance indicators to manage credit, liquidity and other financial risk.

Financial key performance indicators
 
Key performance indicators used by management include assessment of profitability, cash flow and net assets of the company. Executive management monitors each of these indicators on a regular basis against prior periods as well as the budget approved by the board of directors.

Going concern

In December 2019, an outbreak of the COVID-19 virus was reported in Wuhan, China. On March 11, 2020, the World Health Organization declared the COVID-19 virus a global pandemic and on March 13, 2020, President Donald J. Trump declared the virus a national emergency. This highly contagious disease has spread to most of the countries in the world and throughout the United States, creating a serious impact on customers, workforces, and suppliers, disrupting economies and financial markets, and potentially leading to a world-wide economic downturn.
 
The Company notes that the supply chain has continued to operate normally during this time and continues to closely monitor its supply chain to identify any potential shortages before they significantly impact the business. The business is not expecting to have a disruption to its inventory levels. However, any material disruptions would impact revenues. The business is working closely by putting precautions in place internally as well as working closely with its inventory suppliers to minimize any potential impact to the business.
Page 1
 
VERTICE PHARMA UK PARENT LIMITED
 

GROUP STRATEGIC REPORT (CONTINUED)
FOR THE YEAR ENDED 31 DECEMBER 2019


Going concern (continued)

The safety of our employees and customers remains our number one priority. The directors continue to monitor the COVID-19 situation closely and we will continue to follow the recommendations of the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention as well as federal and state authorities.
In addition, management appreciates the support given as a result of the CARES act in the United States. Although the full benefit of taking advantage of some of the business reliefs are still being determined, the business will be benefit from an income tax perspective due to the change in interest deductibility as well as tax payment deferrals.
The directors have considered the impact of COVID-19 on the company's going concern assessment - which included consideration of plausible downsides such as lower hospital visits and postponement of elective surgeries, in conjunction with mitigating factors such as cost reduction initiatives - and continue to approve the financial statements on a going concern basis.
However, these circumstances represent a material uncertainty that may cast significant doubt on the companys ability to continue as a going concern and, therefore, to continue realizing its assets and discharging its liabilities in the normal course of business.  
Refer to note 2.3 for additional details. 

Other key performance indicators
 
The company monitors closely key performance indicators for quality, manufacturing, health and safety and environment to achieve highest compliance standards. 


This report was approved by the board and signed on its behalf.



Scott Meyers 
Director
Date: 5 May 2021

DIRECTORS' REPORT
FOR THE YEAR ENDED 31 DECEMBER 2019

The directors present their report and the financial statements for the year ended 31 December 2019.

Results and dividends

The loss for the year, after taxation, amounted to $8,750,060 (2018 - loss $18,663,540).

During the year, no dividend was declared and paid by the company.

Directors

The directors who served during the year were:

Ruoxi Chen 
Don DeGolyer (resigned 21 September 2020)
Rianne Caroline Schipper 
Cem Behmoaram de Toledo 
Scott Meyers (appointed 8 September 2020)

Political contributions

No political donations to a registered or other political party or any independent election candidate based either
in the EU (including UK) or non-EU were made during the year.

Disclosure of information to auditor

Each of the persons who are directors at the time when this Directors' Report is approved has confirmed that:
 
∙so far as the director is aware, there is no relevant audit information of which the Company and the Group's auditor is unaware, and

∙the director has taken all the steps that ought to have been taken as a director in order to be aware of any relevant audit information and to establish that the Company and the Group's auditor is aware of that information.

Directors' statement of compliance with duty to promote the success of the Group

This section should be read in conjunction with the whole Directors' report. Section 172 of the Companies Act 2006 requires the directors to take into consideration the interests for stakeholders in their decision making. The directors continue to have regard to the interests of the Group's employees and other stakeholders including the impact of its activities on the community, the environment and the Group's reputation when making decisions. Acting in good faith, the directors consider what is most likely to promote the success of the Group for their long term.  Relationships and culture are key factors in promoting this success, which is why understanding the company values are essential to driving performance.  Aligning on these values allow us to fulfil our mission together as one company;
Integrity Everything we do is fair, shows respect for all stakeholders, and is completely transparent.
Teamwork Our people share the same values and are energized to work toward a common goal.
Excellence We are committed to deliver the best results for our customers, employees, partners, and                       shareholders.
Innovation Our sights are set on the future so we can anticipate market needs and steer our company toward sustainable growth.
Customers We are committed to providing high-quality products, reliable supply and an extraordinary customer experience.
In order to understand the issues that arise in the business, the directors engage with stakeholders through regular team meetings and maintain open communication channels.  On a quarterly basis, the leadership team shares key information, strategic priorities, and financial results during company-wide meetings.  Individual departments share further information during smaller team meetings where they can discuss their projects, accomplishments and concerns.

Auditor

Pursuant to Section 487 of the Companies Act 2006, the auditor will be deemed to be reappointed and KPMG
LLP will therefore continue in office.

This report was approved by the board and signed on its behalf.

DIRECTORS' RESPONSIBILITIES STATEMENT
FOR THE YEAR ENDED 31 DECEMBER 2019

The directors are responsible for preparing the Group Strategic Report, the Directors' Report and the consolidated financial statements in accordance with applicable law and regulations.

Company law requires the directors to prepare financial statements for each financial year. Under that law the directors have elected to prepare the financial statements in accordance with applicable law and United Kingdom Accounting Standards (United Kingdom Generally Accepted Accounting Practice), including Financial Reporting Standard 102 The Financial Reporting Standard applicable in the UK and Republic of Ireland'. Under company law the directors must not approve the financial statements unless they are satisfied that they give a true and fair view of the state of affairs of the Company and the Group and of the profit or loss of the Group for that period.

 In preparing these financial statements, the directors are required to:

∙select suitable accounting policies and then apply them consistently;

∙make judgements and accounting estimates that are reasonable and prudent;

∙state whether applicable UK Accounting Standards have been followed, subject to any material departures disclosed and explained in the financial statements;

∙prepare the financial statements on the going concern basis unless it is inappropriate to presume that the Group will continue in business.

The directors are responsible for keeping adequate accounting records that are sufficient to show and explain the Company's transactions and disclose with reasonable accuracy at any time the financial position of the Company and the Group and to enable them to ensure that the financial statements comply with the Companies Act 2006. They are also responsible for safeguarding the assets of the Company and the Group and hence for taking reasonable steps for the prevention and detection of fraud and other irregularities.

INDEPENDENT AUDITOR'S REPORT TO THE MEMBERS OF VERTICE PHARMA UK PARENT LIMITED
 

Opinion

We have audited the financial statements of Vertice Pharma UK Parent Limited (the 'company') for the year ended 31 December 2019 which comprise the Consolidated statement of comprehensive income, Consolidated Balance Sheet, Company Balance Sheet, Consolidated Statement of Changes in Equity, Company Statement of Changes in Equity and Consolidated Cash Flow  and related notes, including the accounting policies in note 2.

In our opinion the financial statements:

∙give a true and fair view of the state of the group's and of the parent company's affairs as at 31 December 2019 and of the group's loss for the year then ended;  

∙have been properly prepared in accordance with UK accounting standards, including FRS 102 The Financial Reporting Standard applicable in the UK and Republic of Ireland; and

∙have been prepared in accordance with the requirements of the Companies Act 2006.

Basis for opinion

We conducted our audit in accordance with International Standards on Auditing (UK) (ISAs (UK)) and applicable law.  Our responsibilities are described below.  We have fulfilled our ethical responsibilities under, and are independent of the group in accordance with, UK ethical requirements including the FRC Ethical Standard. We believe that the audit evidence we have obtained is a sufficient and appropriate basis for our opinion.

Material uncertainty related to going concern

We draw attention to note 2.3 to the financial statements which indicates that the group incurred a loss after tax of $8.75 M for the year and that the group and parent companys abilities to continue as a going concern are dependent on the ability to refinance the debt facility with its lenders as the current facility expires within 12 months of signing these financial statements. These events and conditions, along with the other matters explained in note 2.3, constitute a material uncertainty that may cast significant doubt on the groups and the parent companys ability to continue as a going concern.  
Our opinion is not modified in respect of this matter.

Strategic report and directors' report

The directors are responsible for the strategic report and the directors report.  Our opinion on the financial statements does not cover those reports and we do not express an audit opinion thereon.  
Our responsibility is to read the strategic report and the directors report and, in doing so, consider whether, based on our financial statements audit work, the information therein is materially misstated or inconsistent with the financial statements or our audit knowledge. Based solely on that work:

Strategic report and directors' report (continued)

∙we have not identified material misstatements in the strategic report and the directors report;  

∙in our opinion the information given in those reports for the financial year is consistent with the financial statements; and  

∙in our opinion those reports have been prepared in accordance with the Companies Act 2006.  

Matters on which we are required to report by exception  

Under the Companies Act 2006, we are required to report to you if, in our opinion:  

∙adequate accounting records have not been kept by the parent company, or returns adequate for our audit have not been received from branches not visited by us; or  

∙the parent company financial statements are not in agreement with the accounting records and returns; or
 
∙certain disclosures of directors remuneration specified by law are not made; or  

∙we have not received all the information and explanations we require for our audit.  

We have nothing to report in these respects.  

Directors responsibilities  

As explained more fully in their statement set out on page 9, the directors are responsible for: the preparation of the financial statements and for being satisfied that they give a true and fair view; such internal control as they determine is necessary to enable the preparation of financial statements that are free from material misstatement, whether due to fraud or error; assessing the group and parent companys ability to continue as a going concern, disclosing, as applicable, matters related to going concern; and using the going concern basis of accounting unless they either intend to liquidate the group or the parent company or to cease operations, or have no realistic alternative but to do so.  

Auditor's responsibilities 

Our objectives are to obtain reasonable assurance about whether the financial statements as a whole are free from material misstatement, whether due to fraud or error, and to issue our opinion in an auditors report.  Reasonable assurance is a high level of assurance, but does not guarantee that an audit conducted in accordance with ISAs (UK) will always detect a material misstatement when it exists.  Misstatements can arise from fraud or error and are considered material if, individually or in aggregate, they could reasonably be expected to influence the economic decisions of users taken on the basis of the financial statements. 

A fuller description of our responsibilities is provided on the FRCs website at www.frc.org.uk/auditorsresponsibilities.

NOTES TO THE FINANCIAL STATEMENTS
FOR THE YEAR ENDED 31 DECEMBER 2019

1.


General information

Vertice Pharma UK Parent Limited is a private company, limited by shares, incorporated in England and Wales. The company's registration number is 09835877 and its registered office address is at 25 Moorgate, London, EC2R 6AY.

2.Accounting policies

 
2.1

Basis of preparation of financial statements

The financial statements have been prepared under the historical cost convention unless otherwise specified within these accounting policies and in accordance with Financial Reporting Standard 102, the Financial Reporting Standard applicable in the UK and the Republic of Ireland and the Companies Act 2006.

The preparation of financial statements in compliance with FRS 102 requires the use of certain critical accounting estimates. It also requires Group management to exercise judgement in applying the Group's accounting policies (see note 3).

The Company has taken advantage of the exemption allowed under section 408 of the Companies Act 2006 and has not presented its own Statement of Comprehensive Income in these financial statements.

The following principal accounting policies have been applied:

 
2.2

Basis of consolidation

The consolidated financial statements present the results of the company and its own subsidiaries ("the group") as if they form a single entity. Intercompany transactions and balances between group companies are therefore eliminated in full.
The consolidated financial statements include the financial statements of the Company and its subsidiary undertakings made up to year ended 31 December 2019. A subsidiary is an entity that is controlled by the parent.  The results of subsidiary undertakings are included in the consolidated profit and loss account from the date that control commences until the date that control ceases. Control is established when the Company has the power to govern the operating and financial policies of an entity so as to obtain benefits from its activities.  In assessing control, the Group takes into consideration potential voting rights that are currently exercisable.

Page 19
 
VERTICE PHARMA UK PARENT LIMITED
 
 
 
NOTES TO THE FINANCIAL STATEMENTS
FOR THE YEAR ENDED 31 DECEMBER 2019

2.Accounting policies (continued)

 
2.3

Going concern

As at 31 December 2019 consolidated net assets were $60.2M, consolidated net current assets were $24.7M and a consolidated loss is reported for the year then ended of $8.7M. Notwithstanding the loss made in the year, the financial statements have been prepared on a going concern basis, which the Directors consider to be appropriate for the following reasons. 
The Directors have reviewed the Groups operations and have considered liquidity risk, key assumptions and uncertainties and prepared forecasts until the end of April 2022. As noted above the company has seen minimal disruption in production and continues to closely monitor any supply chain disruptions. Given the nature of the companys business and the essential products provided the company has not seen a material impact from COVID-19 on its overall operations however there has been a reduction in profitability compared to budget as a result of a different sales mix.
The Group has a $153M facility with its lender which was fully drawn down at the date of signing the financial statements. The facility is repayable by 30 April 2022. On March 24, 2021 the company signed an amendment to its credit agreement with its lenders.  Within this agreement, there has been a removal of the previous senior secured net leverage ratio covenant.  This has been replaced with a weekly minimum cash balance requirement of at least $1M until April 30, 2021 and $2M thereafter for the remaining duration of the facility (and is the only financial covenant over the debt).  The Group has passed all covenant tests since the credit agreement was amended on March 24, 2021 and had a cash balance of $8.5M at the last covenant test on 28 April 2021.  In addition, the payment in cash of all interest payments has been waived from February 1, 2021 until the end of the agreement term, and instead, will be added to the overall principal amount of the facility. The ultimate repayment date of the agreement has remained unchanged at April 30, 2022.  Given the debt is due within 12 months of signing these financial statements and  the Company has not yet refinanced the facility with its lenders there exists a material uncertainty in relation to the Companys ability to refinance the debt prior to the maturity date, and to continue as a going concern.
The directors have considered a severe but plausible downside scenario in preparing its future cash flow forecasts which include a reduction of in-line product sales of 10% and a slower ramp of sales of its newly approved product Thyquidity in the period until August 2021 followed by a 25% reduction in sales post August 2021 as compared to the base case. In assessing these cash flow forecasts, the Directors also reviewed the Groups committed borrowing facilities (and the Groups compliance with related weekly cash covenant) as noted above within its borrowing facilities over a twelve month period to 6 May 2022. Within both the severe downside scenario and the base case the Group and company is forecasting compliance with its revised covenants. The company continues to monitor sales of Thyquidity closely, and in the event of a further decrease in the sales the company could stop certain operating costs associated with the product to preserve cash and remain within the current facilities. These actions would be in managements control.
Based on the above circumstances relating to the maturity of the companys debt facility the directors believe that it remains appropriate to prepare the financial statements on a going concern basis.  However, these circumstances represent a material uncertainty that may cast significant doubt on the Group and companys ability to continue as a going concern and, therefore, to continue realizing its assets and discharging its liabilities in the normal course of business.  The financial statements do not include any adjustments that would result from the basis of preparation being inappropriate.

VERTICE PHARMA UK PARENT LIMITED

2.Accounting policies (continued)

 
2.4

Foreign currency translation

Functional and presentation currency

The Company's functional and presentational currency is USD.

Transactions and balances

Foreign currency transactions are translated into the functional currency using the spot exchange rates at the dates of the transactions.

At each period end foreign currency monetary items are translated using the closing rate. Non-monetary items measured at historical cost are translated using the exchange rate at the date of the transaction and non-monetary items measured at fair value are measured using the exchange rate when fair value was determined.

Foreign exchange gains and losses resulting from the settlement of transactions and from the translation at period-end exchange rates of monetary assets and liabilities denominated in foreign currencies are recognised in profit or loss except when deferred in other comprehensive income as qualifying cash flow hedges.

 
2.5

Revenue

Revenue is recognised to the extent that it is probable that the economic benefits will flow to the Group and the revenue can be reliably measured. Revenue is measured as the fair value of the consideration received or receivable, excluding discounts, rebates, returns, value added tax and other sales taxes. 

Sale of goods

Revenue from the sale of goods is recognised when all of the following conditions are satisfied:
∙the Group has transferred the significant risks and rewards of ownership to the buyer;
∙the Group retains neither continuing managerial involvement to the degree usually associated with ownership nor effective control over the goods sold;
∙the amount of revenue can be measured reliably;
∙it is probable that the Group will receive the consideration due under the transaction; and
∙the costs incurred or to be incurred in respect of the transaction can be measured reliably.

Page 21
 
VERTICE PHARMA UK PARENT LIMITED
 
 
 
NOTES TO THE FINANCIAL STATEMENTS
FOR THE YEAR ENDED 31 DECEMBER 2019

2.Accounting policies (continued)

 
2.6

Operating leases: the Group as lessee

Rentals paid under operating leases are charged to profit or loss on a straight line basis over the lease term.

Benefits received and receivable as an incentive to sign an operating lease are recognised on a straight line basis over the lease term, unless another systematic basis is representative of the time pattern of the lessee's benefit from the use of the leased asset.

The Group has taken advantage of the optional exemption available on transition to FRS 102 which allows lease incentives on leases entered into before the date of transition to the standard 01 January 2018 to continue to be charged over the period to the first market rent review rather than the term of the lease.

 
2.7

Leased assets: the Group as lessee

Assets obtained under hire purchase contracts and finance leases are capitalised as tangible fixed assets. Assets acquired by finance lease are depreciated over the shorter of the lease term and their useful lives. Assets acquired by hire purchase are depreciated over their useful lives. Finance leases are those where substantially all of the benefits and risks of ownership are assumed by the company. Obligations under such agreements are included in creditors net of the finance charge allocated to future periods. 

Minimum lease payments are apportioned between the finance charge and the reduction of the outstanding liability using the rate implicit in the lease. The finance charge is allocated to each period during the lease term so as to produce a constant periodic rate of interest on the remaining balance of the liability. Contingent rents are charged as expenses in the periods in which they are incurred.  

 
2.8

Research and development

In the research phase of an internal project it is not possible to demonstrate that the project will generate future economic benefits and hence all expenditure on research shall be recognised as an expense when it is incurred. Intangible assets are recognised from the development phase of a project if and only if certain specific criteria are met in order to demonstrate the asset will generate probable future economic benefits and that its cost can be reliably measured.

All intangible assets shall be considered to have a finite useful life. The useful life of an intangible asset that arises from contractual or other legal rights shall not exceed the period of the contractual or other legal rights, but may be shorter depending on the period over which the entity expects to use the asset. Amortisation begins when the intangible asset is available for use. 

At each reporting date the company assesses whether there is any indication of impairment. If such indication exists, the recoverable amount of the asset is determined which is the higher of its fair value less costs to sell and its value in use. An impairment loss is recognised where the carrying amount exceeds the recoverable amount. 

If it is not possible to distinguish between the research phase and the development phase of an internal project, the expenditure is treated as if it were all incurred in the research phase only.

Page 22
 
VERTICE PHARMA UK PARENT LIMITED
 
 
 
NOTES TO THE FINANCIAL STATEMENTS
FOR THE YEAR ENDED 31 DECEMBER 2019

2.Accounting policies (continued)

 
2.9

Finance costs

Finance costs are charged to profit or loss over the term of the debt using the effective interest method so that the amount charged is at a constant rate on the carrying amount. Issue costs are initially recognised as a reduction in the proceeds of the associated capital instrument.

 
2.10

Borrowing costs

All borrowing costs are recognised in profit or loss in the year in which they are incurred.

 
2.11

Share based payments

Where share options are awarded to employees, the fair value of the options at the date of grant is charged to profit or loss over the vesting period. Non-market vesting conditions are taken into account by adjusting the number of equity instruments expected to vest at each Balance Sheet date so that, ultimately, the cumulative amount recognised over the vesting period is based on the number of options that eventually vest. Market vesting conditions are factored into the fair value of the options granted. The cumulative expense is not adjusted for failure to achieve a market vesting condition.
The fair value of the award also takes into account non-vesting conditions. These are either factors beyond the control of either party (such as a target based on an index) or factors which are within the control of one or other of the parties (such as the Group keeping the scheme open or the employee maintaining any contributions required by the scheme).
Where the terms and conditions of options are modified before they vest, the increase in the fair value of the options, measured immediately before and after the modification, is also charged to profit or loss over the remaining vesting period.
Where equity instruments are granted to persons other than employees, profit or loss is charged with fair value of goods and services received.

Page 23
 
VERTICE PHARMA UK PARENT LIMITED
 
 
 
NOTES TO THE FINANCIAL STATEMENTS
FOR THE YEAR ENDED 31 DECEMBER 2019

2.Accounting policies (continued)

 
2.12

Current and deferred taxation

The tax expense for the year comprises current and deferred tax. Tax is recognised in profit or loss except that a charge attributable to an item of income and expense recognised as other comprehensive income or to an item recognised directly in equity is also recognised in other comprehensive income or directly in equity respectively.

The current income tax charge is calculated on the basis of tax rates and laws that have been enacted or substantively enacted by the balance sheet date in the countries where the Company and the Group operate and generate income.

Deferred tax balances are recognised in respect of all timing differences that have originated but not reversed by the Balance Sheet date, except that:
∙The recognition of deferred tax assets is limited to the extent that it is probable that they will be recovered against the reversal of deferred tax liabilities or other future taxable profits;
∙Any deferred tax balances are reversed if and when all conditions for retaining associated tax allowances have been met; and
∙Where they relate to timing differences in respect of interests in subsidiaries, associates, branches and joint ventures and the Group can control the reversal of the timing differences and such reversal is not considered probable in the foreseeable future.

Deferred tax balances are not recognised in respect of permanent differences except in respect of business combinations, when deferred tax is recognised on the differences between the fair values of assets acquired and the future tax deductions available for them and the differences between the fair values of liabilities acquired and the amount that will be assessed for tax. Deferred tax is determined using tax rates and laws that have been enacted or substantively enacted by the balance sheet date.

2.Accounting policies (continued)

 
2.13

Intangible assets

Goodwill
Goodwill is stated at cost less any accumulated amortisation and accumulated impairment losses. Goodwill is allocated to cash-generating units or group of cash-generating units that are expected to benefit from synergies of the business combination from which it arose. 

Negative goodwill 

Negative goodwill arising on business combinations in respect of acquisitions is included on the balance sheet immediately below any positive goodwill and released to the profit and loss account in the periods in which the non-monetary assets arising on the same acquisition are recovered.  Any excess exceeding the fair value of non-monetary assets acquired shall be recognised in profit or loss in the periods expected to benefit.
Other intangible assets
Intangible assets are initially recognised at cost and subsequently measured at cost less and accumulated amortisation. 
All intangible assets shall be considered to have a finite useful life. The useful life of an intangible asset that arises from contractual or other legal rights shall not exceed the period of the contractual or other legal rights, but may be shorter depending on the period over which the entity expects to use the asset.
Amortisation begins when the intangible asset is available for use.

2.14

Tangible fixed assets

Tangible fixed assets under the cost model are stated at historical cost less accumulated depreciation and any accumulated impairment losses. Historical cost includes expenditure that is directly attributable to bringing the asset to the location and condition necessary for it to be capable of operating in the manner intended by management.

At each reporting date the company assesses whether there is any indication of impairment. If such indication exists, the recoverable amount of the asset is determined which is the higher of its fair value less costs to sell and its value in use. An impairment loss is recognised where the carrying amount exceeds the recoverable amount.

Land is not depreciated. Depreciation on other assets is charged so as to allocate the cost of assets less their residual value over their estimated useful lives, using the straight-line method.

The assets' residual values, useful lives and depreciation methods are reviewed, and adjusted prospectively if appropriate, or if there is an indication of a significant change since the last reporting date.

Gains and losses on disposals are determined by comparing the proceeds with the carrying amount and are recognised in profit or loss.

Construction in progress relates to various projects in progress which are not depreciated and reviewed for impairment each period. 

  
2.15

Impairment of fixed assets and goodwill

Assets that are subject to depreciation or amortisation are assessed at each balance sheet date to determine whether there is any indication that the assets are impaired.
 
Where there is any indication that an asset may be impaired, the carrying value of the asset (or cash-generating unit to which the asset has been allocated) is tested for impairment. An impairment loss is recognised for the amount by which the asset's carrying amount exceeds its recoverable amount. The recoverable amount is the higher of an asset's (or CGUs) fair value less costs to sell and value in use.
For the purposes of assessing impairment, assets are grouped at the lowest levels for which there are separately identifiable cash flows (CGUs). Non-financial assets that have previously been impaired are reviewed at each balance sheet date to assess whether there is any indication that the impairment losses recognised in prior periods may no longer exist or may have decreased.

Page 26
 
VERTICE PHARMA UK PARENT LIMITED
 
 
 
NOTES TO THE FINANCIAL STATEMENTS
FOR THE YEAR ENDED 31 DECEMBER 2019

2.Accounting policies (continued)

 
2.16

Impairment of fixed assets and goodwill

Assets that are subject to depreciation or amortisation are assessed at each balance sheet date to determine whether there is any indication that the assets are impaired. Where there is any indication that an asset may be impaired, the carrying value of the asset (or cash-generating unit to which the asset has been allocated) is tested for impairment. An impairment loss is recognised for the amount by which the asset's carrying amount exceeds its recoverable amount. The recoverable amount is the higher of an asset's (or CGU's) fair value less costs to sell and value in use. For the purposes of assessing impairment, assets are grouped at the lowest levels for which there are separately identifiable cash flows (CGUs). Non-financial assets that have been previously impaired are reviewed at each balance sheet date to assess whether there is any indication that the impairment losses recognised in prior periods may no longer exist or may have decreased. An impairment loss recognised for goodwill is not reversed. Impairment losses recognised for other assets is reversed only if the reasons for the impairment have ceased to apply.

 
2.17

Valuation of investments

Investments in subsidiaries are measured at cost less accumulated impairment.

 
2.18

Stocks

Stocks are stated at the lower of cost and net realisable value, being the estimated selling price less costs to complete and sell. Cost is based on the cost of purchase on a first in, first outbasis. Work in progress and finished goods include labour and attributable overheads.

At each balance sheet date, stocks are assessed for impairment. If stock is impaired, the carrying amount is reduced to its selling price less costs to complete and sell. The impairment loss is recognised immediately in profit or loss.

 
2.19

Debtors

Short term debtors are measured at transaction price, less any impairment. Loans receivable are measured initially at fair value, net of transaction costs, and are measured subsequently at amortised cost using the effective interest method, less any impairment.

 
2.20

Cash and cash equivalents

Cash is represented by cash in hand and deposits with financial institutions repayable without penalty on notice of not more than 24 hours. Cash equivalents are highly liquid investments that mature in no more than three months from the date of acquisition and that are readily convertible to known amounts of cash with insignificant risk of change in value.

In the Consolidated Statement of Cash Flows, cash and cash equivalents are shown net of bank overdrafts that are repayable on demand and form an integral part of the Group's cash management.

 
2.21

Creditors

Short term creditors are measured at the transaction price. Other financial liabilities, including bank loans, are measured initially at fair value, net of transaction costs, and are measured subsequently at amortised cost using the effective interest method.

Page 27
 
VERTICE PHARMA UK PARENT LIMITED
 
 
 
NOTES TO THE FINANCIAL STATEMENTS
FOR THE YEAR ENDED 31 DECEMBER 2019

2.Accounting policies (continued)

 
2.22

Provisions for liabilities

Provisions are made where an event has taken place that gives the Group a legal or constructive obligation that probably requires settlement by a transfer of economic benefit, and a reliable estimate can be made of the amount of the obligation.
Provisions are charged as an expense to profit or loss in the year that the Group becomes aware of the obligation, and are measured at the best estimate at the Balance Sheet date of the expenditure required to settle the obligation, taking into account relevant risks and uncertainties.
When payments are eventually made, they are charged to the provision carried in the Balance Sheet.

Page 28
 
VERTICE PHARMA UK PARENT LIMITED
 
 
 
NOTES TO THE FINANCIAL STATEMENTS
FOR THE YEAR ENDED 31 DECEMBER 2019

2.Accounting policies (continued)

 
2.23

Financial instruments

The Group only enters into basic financial instrument transactions that result in the recognition of financial assets and liabilities like trade and other debtors and creditors, loans from banks and other third parties, loans to related parties and investments in ordinary shares.

Debt instruments (other than those wholly repayable or receivable within one year), including loans and other accounts receivable and payable, are initially measured at present value of the future cash flows and subsequently at amortised cost using the effective interest method. Debt instruments that are payable or receivable within one year, typically trade debtors and creditors, are measured, initially and subsequently, at the undiscounted amount of the cash or other consideration expected to be paid or received. However, if the arrangements of a short-term instrument constitute a financing transaction, like the payment of a trade debt deferred beyond normal business terms or in case of an out-right short-term loan that is not at market rate, the financial asset or liability is measured, initially at the present value of future cash flows discounted at a market rate of interest for a similar debt instrument and subsequently at amortised cost, unless it qualifies as a loan from a director in the case of a small company, or a public benefit entity concessionary loan.

Investments in non-derivative instruments that are equity to the issuer are measured:
∙at fair value with changes recognised in the Consolidated Statement of Comprehensive Income if the shares are publicly traded or their fair value can otherwise be measured reliably;
∙at cost less impairment for all other investments.

Financial assets that are measured at cost and amortised cost are assessed at the end of each reporting period for objective evidence of impairment. If objective evidence of impairment is found, an impairment loss is recognised in the Consolidated Statement of Comprehensive Income.

For financial assets measured at amortised cost, the impairment loss is measured as the difference between an asset's carrying amount and the present value of estimated cash flows discounted at the asset's original effective interest rate. If a financial asset has a variable interest rate, the discount rate for measuring any impairment loss is the current effective interest rate determined under the contract.

For financial assets measured at cost less impairment, the impairment loss is measured as the difference between an asset's carrying amount and best estimate of the recoverable amount, which is an approximation of the amount that the Group would receive for the asset if it were to be sold at the balance sheet date.

Financial assets and liabilities are offset and the net amount reported in the Balance Sheet when there is an enforceable right to set off the recognised amounts and there is an intention to settle on a net basis or to realise the asset and settle the liability simultaneously.

3.


Judgements in applying accounting policies and key sources of estimation uncertainty

The preparation of consolidated financial statements in conformity with  accounting standards accepted in the United Kingdom requires management to make estimates and assumptions that affect the reported amounts of assets and liabilities and the disclosure of contingent assets and liabilities at the date of the consolidated financial statements and the reported amounts of revenues and expenses during the reporting period. Actual results could differ from these estimates. 

Accounts that are subject to management estimates include debtor balances, stocks, share-based compensation, deferred tax provision and creditor balances due within one year. Debtor balances include significant provisions for chargebacks and actual chargebacks could differ from those estimates.

Factors that may affect future tax charges

The Company is not reporting a profit, and as of December 31, 2019 and 2018, the Company has approximately $8.5 million and $8.4 million of federal net operating loss carry forwards, respectively, and approximately $14.0 million and $14.6 million of state net operating loss carry forwards, respectively. The federal and state net operating loss carry forwards begin to expire in 2036. Management have chosen not to recognise a deferred tax assets of $3,177,400 on losses on the basis that these assets are not likely to be realised based on current reporting losses.  Utilization of the net operating losses may be subject to substantial annual limitations under Section 382 of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 due to ownership change limitations that could occur in the future. These previous ownership changes may limit the amount of net operating loss carry forwards that can be utilized annually to offset future taxable income and tax.

The calculation of our tax liabilities involves dealing with uncertainties in the application of complex tax laws and regulations in several jurisdictions. Because of the complexity of some of these uncertainties, the ultimate resolution may result in a payment that is different from our current estimate. These differences will be reflected as increases or decreases to income tax expense in the period in which new information is available. The Company's policy is to recognize interest and penalties related to tax matters within the income tax provision.  During 2019, the Company completed a Federal income tax audit for 2016 that did not have a material impact to the Company.

The EU Commission issued a press release on April 2, 2019 confirming its position that the UK finance company exemption under the UK controlled foreign company rules constitutes illegal state aid, in circumstances where there are UK activities involved. The full decision has not been published and may be subject to further legal process. Accordingly, where a group has been applying the finance company exemption and the arrangements involved UK activities, income previously treated as exempt may now be taxable for UK tax purposes. There are numerous companies in the UK where the EU decision may apply. The Company applied the finance company exemption on its 2016 and 2017 tax returns. The Company received a formal inquiry in July 2019 which it responded to in October of 2019. In its response, Management highlighted that its facts fall within the exemption on the basis that no UK activities were involved in the arrangements and accordingly, no additional income should be treated as taxable for UK

During August 2019, the Company sold three properties in Largo, Florida to STORE Capital Corporation
for $10,000,000 up front and up to an additional $5,000,000 for construction financing for qualifying improvements. There were no draw downs of the constructing financing in the year ended December 31, 2019. The Company determined that the transaction qualifies for sale leaseback accounting as there is no continuing involvement by the Company. The gain on the sale is being deferred and amortized over the initial lease period as the Company is retaining the right to substantially all of the use of the property. The deferred gain remaining as of December 31, 2019 is $570,456 of which $538,166 is in other long term liabilities and the remainder in accrued liabilities. In addition, the Company assessed the lease and determined that it qualifies as an operating lease.

During September 2019, the Company entered into a factoring arrangement with LiquidX, Inc., acting as a platform administrator and collateral agent, whereby it sells select accounts receivable to third party buyers.

Under the terms of the agreement, the Company may sell select accounts receivable at 50% of their value subject to a discount of LIBOR plus 5.0%. Fees paid to the platform administrator are nominal. There is no continuing involvement with the transferred financial assets. There were no factored receivables outstanding as of December 31, 2019.

The Company's factor expense is recorded as other expense, net in the consolidated statement of operations and totalled $15,304 for the year ended December 31, 2019.

20.


Loans

The Company through its subsidiaries entered into a credit agreement on December 21, 2015 with a lending group to borrow $100 million and secure a $10 million revolving line of credit.  The $100 million principal requires quarterly principal repayments of $250,000 starting on March 31, 2016 with successive quarterly principal repayments until the remaining principal amount of $94.25 million becomes due on December 20, 2021.  Net proceeds from the borrowing of approximately $96.8 million were combined with the funds raised from the initial capitalization of the Company to close on the acquisition of VistaPharm. Concurrent with the execution of the credit agreement, the Company through its subsidiaries entered into a Collateral Agreement with the lenders effectively pledging 100% of the equity interest in VistaPharm, Inc. as collateral on the amounts borrowed. 
On November 6, 2017, the Company entered into Amendment #1 to the credit agreement (Amendment).   The Amendment provided for incremental borrowings of $56.75 million along with increasing the revolving line of credit to $15 million in exchange for a 50 basis point increase in the interest rate.  The quarterly principal repayments were modified to include the incremental borrowings, but the maturity remained unchanged.  Net borrowings of $54.6 million were used to fund the dividend and return of capital totaling $39.75 million and repay $9.93 million outstanding on the revolving line of credit with the remaining borrowings used to support working capital.  The Amendment was not considered a material modification.  
 
The debt principal bears interest at an Alternate Base Rate or "ABR" rate per annum plus an Applicable Rate.  The ABR is equal to the greatest of (a) the Prime Rate, (b) the Federal Funds Effective Rate plus 50 basis points and c) the Adjusted LIBOR Rate for a deposit in dollars with a maturity of one month plus 1%.  The interest rate will be deemed to be 2% if the rate calculated pursuant to the foregoing would otherwise be less than 2% per annum.  Any change in the Prime Rate, Federal Funds Effective Rate or the Adjusted LIBOR Rate shall be effective from and including the effective date of such change.  
The Company may elect to convert some or all of the principal outstanding to Eurodollar Borrowings which bear interest at the Adjusted LIBOR Rate for the interest period selected plus the Applicable Rate.  Interest is payable a) quarterly with respect to any ABR borrowings or b) with respect to Eurodollar borrowings, the last day of the interest period applicable to the borrowing, but no less than every three months if the Eurodollar term selected is greater than three months.
As of December 31, 2019 and 2018, the interest rate in effect was 7.9% and 8.1%, respectively.  For the year ended December 31, 2019 and 2018, interest expense, net was $14,723,672 and $13,790,659, respectively.
The term debt includes a revolving line of credit of up to $10 million with a maturity date of December 21, 2020 (the "Revolver").  In connection with the November 2017 Amendment, the line was increased to $15 million.  As of December 31, 2019 there was $7.0 million of borrowings outstanding on the Revolver. During March 2020, an additional $3.0 million was borrowed under the Revolver. As of December 31, 2018 there were no borrowings outstanding on the Revolver.  The Revolver provides for the issuance of letters of credit against the available borrowings of which $74,400 was issued and outstanding as of December 31, 2019.  To the extent that the Revolver is unfunded, the Company pays a fee of 5 basis points which the Company recognizes as selling, general and administrative expense.  For the years ended December 31, 2019 and 2018, the unfunded fee charged to selling, general and administrative expense was $41,323 and $76,079, respectively.

24.


Share capital

Holders of Ordinary Shares are voting shares only and are entitled to receive notice of, attend, speak and vote at any general meeting of the Company.  Otherwise, holders of Ordinary Shares do not have any economic interest in the Company.  Holders of Preferred Shares, A Ordinary Shares and Participation Unit for Excess Equity Value Plan are not entitled to receive notice of, attend, speak and vote at any general meeting of the Company.  Preferred Shares accrue dividends at a rate of 8% per annum.  After the distribution to holders of Participation Units, any distribution to A Ordinary Shares must first satisfy Preferred Share capital of $101,990,209 and cumulative accrued dividends of $18,957,231 as of 31 December 2019.  Amounts available for distribution after the full satisfaction of the Preferred dividends and return of Preferred Share capital are distributed pro rata to holders of A Ordinary Shares and Preferred Shares, and for this purpose it shall be deemed that each Preferred Share is converted to an A Ordinary Share.

During 2019, 3,080 Preferred Shares were authorized and issued for $48,787 and 4,067 Preferred Shares were repurchased from a departing executive for $64,405.

26.


Reserves

Share premium account

Share premium account represents the amount above the nominal value received for shares sold, less transaction costs. As of December 31, 2019 the total share premium account balance of $49,638 is made up of 16,841 ordinary shares with share premium amount of $22,398 and 3,080 preferred shares with share premium amount of $27,227.

Capital redemption reserve

Capital redemption reserve represents the amount of capital replenished following the cancellation of shares.

Other reserves

Other reserves include the share option reserve and the amount represents the share option reserve provisions. During 2019, $265,258 share options were granted and the share option reserve balance as of December 31, 2019 is $1,991,013 (2018: $1,725,755).

Profit and loss account

Profit & loss account reserves represent consolidated accumulated profits and losses.

27.


Share based compensation

Certain executives participate in a share incentive plan known as the Vertice Pharma UK Parent Limited 2015 Share Incentive Plan or the "Plan".  Under the Plan the Company is authorized to issue up to 10 million A Ordinary Shares representing up to 25% of the combined outstanding shares of Preferred and A Ordinary Shares of the Company. These options are stratified into three tranches.   

Tranche 1 Options:  subject to certain limitations, the Tranche 1 Options vest as follows:(i) 16% of the Tranche 1 Options shall vest on each of the first five (5) anniversaries of the Vesting Commencement Date and (ii) 20% of the Tranche 1 Options shall vest on the earlier to occur of (A) a Change of Control and (B) an initial public offering of the Company.

Tranche 2 Options:  subject to certain limitations, the Tranche 2 Options vest as follows:100% of the Tranche 2 Options shall vest as of the date of any realization event that results in achievement of the Tranche 2 IRR and MOIC. In connection with a Change of Control, if the Tranche 2 IRR and MOIC targets are not achieved, all Tranche 2 Options, to the extent not previously forfeited, will be forfeited upon such Change of Control with no consideration therefore.

Tranche 3 Options:  subject to certain limitations, the Tranche 3 Options vest as follows: Provided that the participant has not undergone a termination prior to each applicable vesting date, 100% of the Tranche 3 Options shall vest as of the date of any Realization Event that results in achievement of the Tranche 3 IRR and MOIC. In connection with a Change of Control, if the Tranche 3 IRR and MOIC targets are not achieved, all Tranche 3 Options, to the extent not previously forfeited, will be forfeited upon such Change of Control with no consideration therefore. 

As of December 31, 2019 and 2018, 4,066,145 options had been authorized under the Plan.  As of December 31, 2019 and 2018, 3,344,988 and 3,106,718 options have been granted or repurchased, net of forfeitures, respectively.  Except for 294,391 Tranche 1 options granted on or after September 1, 2017 which has a strike price of $3.22, the strike price for all remaining Tranche 1 grants was established at $1.33.  The strike price for Tranche 2 and 3 options are calculated at the time of a vesting event based on a predetermined formula.  The total option period under the Plan and the weighted average life of the shares granted is ten years.  The total remaining unrecognized compensation expense as of December 31, 2019 related to non-vested stock options, excluding options that vest upon a change of control, amounted to $1,134,862, which will be amortized over the weighted-average remaining requisite vesting period of approximately 2.4 years.

The Company valued the options using the guidance contained in Valuation of Privately-Held-Company Equity Securities Issued as Compensation, a practice aid published by the American Institute of Certified Public Accountants.  Specifically, the option pricing model was utilized using an expected share option life of 5 years, expected volatility of 50%, risk-free interest rate of 1.77%, and zero expected dividend yield.  Each tranche of options were further discounted for lack of marketability ranging from 50% to 60%.  The resulting per share value was determined to be $1.33, $0.81 and $0.49 for Tranche 1, Tranche 2 and Tranche 3 options, respectively.  During 2017, the Company updated its valuation resulting in option values of $2.95, $1.88 and $1.05 for Tranche 1, Tranche 2 and Tranche 3 options, respectively.  During 2019, the Company updated its valuation resulting in option values of $2.21, $1.23 and $0.45 for Tranche 1, Tranche 2 and Tranche 3 options, respectively. The aggregate fair value of the options totaling approximately $4.0 million is being amortized to compensation expense over the expected vesting period of five years or upon a Change in Control.  As of December 31, 2019, 1,600,558 options granted have vested.  Stock-based compensation expense for the years ended December 31, 2019 and 2018 was $265,258 and $562,239, respectively and is included in selling, general and administrative expense.

The Company expects to continue its practice of issuing share options which will result in additional share-based compensation in the future, although amounts may vary.

27.


Share based compensation (continued)

In addition to the share based compensation plan, during 2019, a new excess equity value bonus plan was offered to key employees. This is a cash bonus plan that is triggered upon a change of control event in which the bonus is calculated based on a percentage of excess equity generated. As the bonus is triggered upon a change of control event, it was not deemed probable as of December 31, 2019.


28.


Contingent liabilities

On April 2019, the Company received a letter from The City of Parkersburg, West Virginia notifying the Company that Vista Pharm, Inc. is added to the list of defendants in the case City of Parkersburg v. AmeriscourceBergen Drug Corp. et al. in the National Prescription Opiate Litigation.  The Company was voluntarily dismissed from this litigation.
In September 2019 and March 2020, the Company received letters from the Department of Justice (DoJ) in relation to the Drug Enforcement Agencys (DEA) observation regarding the Companys failure to keep adequate recordkeeping of controlled substances. These observations were following a July 2018 audit of the facility by the DEA. The Company has reconciled discrepancies since then and maintains adequate recordkeeping of controlled substances.  The Company met DoJ representatives in December 2019 and continues to work with DoJ on a settlement to resolve the matters outlined in their letters. As of December 31, 2019, the Company has recorded an estimated settlement of $175,000 which is included in accrued liabilities.


29.


Pension commitments

The group operates a defined contributions pension scheme. The assets of the scheme are held separately from those of the group in an independently administered fund. The pension cost charge represents contributions payable by the group  to the fund and amounted to $487,212 (2018 - $369,268). Contributions totalling $nil (2018 - $nil) were payable to the fund at the balance sheet date and are included in creditors.

31.


Related party transactions

During 2019 and 2018, the Company engaged a consulting firm to support quality improvement initiatives to address known quality issues as identified by the FDA during recent inspections.  The Chairman of the Board of the consulting firm used to support the quality improvement initiatives also serves on the Board of the Company.  This Board member excused himself from selecting the consulting firm used. Total fees incurred during 2019 and 2018 were $908,225 and $8,743,092, respectively and are included in selling, general and administrative expenses in the accompanying consolidated statements of operations.  As of December 31, 2019,  there were no unpaid fees for consulting services rendered.


32.


Post balance sheet events

On April 6, 2020, the Company entered into Amendment #2 to the credit agreement (Second Amendment). The Second Amendment extended the terms of the revolver and term loans to April 30, 2022. In addition, the net leverage ratio was reset starting with the first measurement period ending March 31, 2020 with a net leverage ratio not to exceed 6.25:1 increasing to 8.25:1 by March 31, 2021 then reducing to 5.75:1 by March 31, 2022 and each quarterly test period ending thereafter until maturity. Further, the Second Amendment provides for a change in the Applicable Rate to range from 5.0% to 7.5% on ABR borrowings and from 6.0% to 8.5% on Eurodollar borrowings based on the total net leverage ratio as defined within the agreement. The Company has an election to pay the difference between the interest payment calculated based on the Applicable Rate and the interest payment calculated based on the lowest percentage in the Applicable Rate range either in i) cash or ii) by adding the amount to the outstanding principal amount. In connection with the Second Amendment, there was an equity contribution of $12.5 million which was used first to pay down the outstanding revolver balance at the time of the Second Amendment of $10.0 million and pay fees of approximately $1.0 million for net proceeds of approximately $1.5 million. Extended maturity, increased net leverage ratio and headroom created in the revolver loan by paying down the outstanding amount using the equity contribution will position the company to pursue future growth through Business Development and Licensing and internal R&D projects.
On March 24, 2021, the Company entered into Amendment No. 7 to the credit agreement (Seventh Amendment). The Seventh Amendment removed the previous senior secured net leverage ratio covenant and added a weekly minimum cash balance requirement of at least $1M until April 30, 2021 and $2M thereafter for the remaining duration of the facility.  This liquidity covenant is now the only financial maintenance covenant in the facility.  In addition, the payment of all interest payments in cash has been waived from February 1, 2021 until the end of the agreement and will be added to the overall debt repayment at maturity. The ultimate repayment date of the agreement has remained unchanged at April 30, 2022. 
Also as part of the Seventh Amendment, Warburg Pincus (investor group) funded an additional $6 million of debt to the Company for working capital purposes.  The additional debt is treated pari passu to the existing Term Loan and Revolver debt with interest accruing and being capitalized through maturity of April 30, 2022.


33.


Controlling party

Vertice is majority owned by several private equity funds managed by Warburg Pincus, LLC and was initially capitalised through a private equity offering totalling approximately $122 million that funded immediately prior to the Company's acquisition of VistaPharm, Inc. at the close of business on 21 December 2015.
